speaker: Sophie
text: So, Alex, how are you settling into the team?
ipa: soʊ ˈælɪks, haʊ ɑːr juː ˈsɛtlɪŋ ˈɪntuː ðə tiːm?
linking: "how are you" → /haʊ ɑːr juː/ (r + y linking)

speaker: Alex
text: Pretty well, thanks! Everyone who works here has been super helpful. Especially Daniel, who helped me set up my dev environment.
ipa: ˈprɪti wɛl, θæŋks! ˈɛvrɪwʌn huː wɜːrks hɪər hæz bɪn ˈsuːpər ˈhɛlpfʊl. ɪˈspɛʃəli ˈdænjəl, huː hɛlpt miː sɛt ʌp maɪ dɛv ɪnˈvaɪrənmənt.

speaker: Sophie
text: Yeah, Daniel’s great. He’s the engineer whose pull requests are always spotless. You’ll learn a lot from him.
ipa: jæ, ˈdænjəlz ɡreɪt. hiːz ði ˌɛnʤɪˈnɪə huːz pʊl rɪˈkwɛsts ɑːr ˈɔːlweɪz ˈspɒtləs. juːl lɜːn ə lɒt frəm hɪm.

speaker: Alex
text: I hope so! I’m still figuring out parts of the codebase, like the auth module that handles user sessions.
ipa: aɪ həʊp səʊ! aɪm stɪl ˈfɪɡərɪŋ aʊt pɑːts əv ðə ˈkəʊdbeɪs, laɪk ði ɔːθ ˈmɒdjuːl ðæt ˈhændlz ˈjuːzə ˈsɛʃənz.

speaker: Sophie
text: Ah yes, that’s one of the components which we rewrote last quarter. It connects to a microservice that validates tokens.
ipa: ɑː jɛs, ðæts wʌn əv ðə kəmˈpəʊnənts wɪʧ wiː ˌriːˈrəʊt lɑːst ˈkwɔːtə. ɪt kəˈnɛkts tuː ə ˈmaɪkrəʊsɜːvɪs ðæt ˈvælɪdeɪts ˈtəʊkənz.

speaker: Alex
text: I noticed! I also ran into a utility that logs errors but couldn’t find the person who wrote it.
ipa: aɪ ˈnəʊtɪst! aɪ ˈɔːlsəʊ ræn ˈɪntuː ə juːˈtɪlɪti ðæt lɒɡz ˈɛrəz bət ˈkʊdnt faɪnd ðə ˈpɜːsən huː rəʊt ɪt.

speaker: Sophie
text: That was Sam — he’s the one who onboarded me, actually. He left a few months ago, which is a shame. He documented things really well, which makes your life easier now.
ipa: ðæt wəz sæm — hiːz ðə wʌn huː ɒnˈbɔːdɪd miː, ˈækʧuəli. hiː lɛft ə fjuː mʌnθs əˈɡəʊ, wɪʧ ɪz ə ʃeɪm. hiː ˈdɒkjʊmɛntɪd θɪŋz ˈrɪəli wɛl, wɪʧ meɪks jɔː laɪf ˈiːzɪə naʊ.

speaker: Alex
text: Yeah, absolutely. I found a README that explains the database setup, and it saved me hours.
ipa: jæ, ˌæbsəˈluːtli. aɪ faʊnd ə ˈriːdmi ðæt ɪksˈpleɪnz ðə ˈdeɪtəbeɪs ˈsɛtʌp, ənd ɪt seɪvd miː ˈaʊəz.

speaker: Sophie
text: We try to leave good documentation. The repos that are actively maintained usually have decent instructions.
ipa: wiː traɪ tuː liːv ɡʊd ˌdɒkjʊmɛnˈteɪʃən. ðə ˈriːpəʊz ðæt ɑːr ˈæktɪvli meɪnˈteɪnd ˈjuːʒuəli hæv ˈdiːsənt ɪnˈstrʌkʃənz.

speaker: Alex
text: By the way, do you know any tools that can help me visualize dependencies?
ipa: baɪ ðə weɪ, duː juː nəʊ ˈɛni tuːlz ðæt kən hɛlp miː ˈvɪʒʊəlaɪz dɪˈpɛndənsiz?

speaker: Sophie
text: We use a script that generates architecture diagrams from the codebase. I’ll send it to you.
ipa: wiː juːz ə skrɪpt ðæt ˈʤɛnəreɪts ˈɑːkɪtɛkʧə ˈdaɪəɡræmz frəm ðə ˈkəʊdbeɪs. aɪl sɛnd ɪt tuː juː.

speaker: Alex
text: Perfect. Also, I joined the Slack group where devs share best practices. Lots of good threads there.
ipa: ˈpɜːfɪkt. ˈɔːlsəʊ, aɪ ʤɔɪnd ðə slæk ɡruːp weə dɛvz ʃeə bɛst ˈpræktɪsɪz. lɒts əv ɡʊd θrɛdz ðeə.

speaker: Sophie
text: Nice! We also have a monthly tech talk where people showcase tools they’ve built or used.
ipa: naɪs! wiː ˈɔːlsəʊ hæv ə ˈmʌnθli tɛk tɔːk weə ˈpiːpl ˈʃəʊkeɪs tuːlz ðeɪv bɪlt ɔː juːzd.
